answers.author: Barry Crook
answers.text:
We judge our performance in two ways: (1) from the strategic perspective of the City Council -- we have a set of Top Ten goals that they establish in an annual retreat setting, and (2) every department has an operational plan and set of goals & outcome measures to measure our "daily work". That document for the City Manager's Office is attached.

answers.author: Gerald Young
answers.text:
The ICMA Center for Performance Measurement’s General Government survey collects data on citizen satisfaction with regard to all jurisdiction services.  Beyond that, most of the center’s measures focus on individual departments (police, fire, highways, parks) or outcomes (sustainability, employee satisfaction).
Among the measures that have been used by various local governments are those that are goal-specific (e.g., completion of a key capital improvement on a pre-set timeline, satisfactory resolution of labor or economic development negotiations), process-specific (relating to budget calendars, citizen-inquiry responsiveness, process streamlining), or internally focused (employee development, evaluation and retention; responsiveness to council referrals).  The danger with some such measures, of course, is that they boil down a complex task into a simple question of workload.
Some jurisdictions also use “meta-measures” for management, looking at how they are driving change within the organization.  The City of San Jose, California, for instance, has measured the manager’s performance on the percentage of core services meeting or exceeding levels established by the council, the percentage using formal customer feedback mechanisms to improve service delivery, and the percentage exceeding cycle time targets.
Another good resource is the city of Vancouver, Wash.  While the city manager’s goals are stated in summary form, each department (including financial and management services) has a scorecard that details its progress against goals and discusses any issues encountered.  Looking at longer-range management, they have also encouraged departments to adopt multi-year business plans, and allow for streamlined consideration of budget requests if they are part of those plans.  
http://www.cityofvancouver.us/performance.asp?menuid=10462&submenuID=17767&itemID=17770

author: Susan Thorpe
text:
We are preparing our budget and reviewing performance measures for all departments. The City manager's office seems to be a difficult one for us to articulate performance measures for.  I'd appreciate any specific measures you use or would suggest.  Thanks in advance for your help!
Susan Thorpe, Deputy City Manager, Peoria AZ
title: City Manager's Office Performance measures?
